title: Blind Runner
subtitle: An article about Simon Wheatcroft, a blind athlete who runs marathons and ultra-marathons.

cards.text: For the past two years Simon, now 29, has been overcoming his disability to compete in marathons and ultra-marathons by training with guides, and also, rather uniquely, by teaching himself to run solo. ‘I got bored exercising indoors, so thought, I’ll have a go at running outside,’ he explains. ... Then he got bored again and wanted to try running on the roads.
cards.question: Which sentence explains how Simon first trained outside?
choices: He began by training on football pitches behind his house, running between the goalposts.

cards.text: Weeks of gradual exploration followed, walking a route alone ... It took him along little-used pavements alongside a busy main road.
cards.question: Which sentence explains the result of this gradual exploration?
choices: As a result of this slow experimentation, he was able to memorise a set five-kilometre course.

cards.text: Now, having covered hundreds of km alone, Simon has been able, gradually, to phase out the app. ‘When I first started I had to really concentrate to an unbelievable level to know where my feet were falling. Now it has become quite automated.’ ... ‘I did make a few mistakes early on – like running into posts.’

cards.text: Joining Simon for a training session, it’s striking how natural and fluid his movement is: he takes short, gentle steps, using his feet to feel his way. His landmarks are minute changes in gradient and slight variations in the surface. ... ‘I have to believe this route is going to stay consistent, and there won’t be things like roadwork signs or rocks,’ he says.

cards.text: When it comes to racing in ultra-distance events, Simon has to use guides to run stretches of the course with him; it would be almost impossible to memorise 150 km of countryside. However, the advantages of training outdoors, on his own terms, are vast and have boosted his confidence as well as providing inspiration to others. ...

cards.text: But for Simon the real thrill and motivation for training come from simply being able to compete on equal terms. ... ‘I’m blind,’ he says, ‘but at the same time I’d rather compete with everybody else and not be put into a special group.’
cards.question: Which sentence sums up Simon’s attitude toward competition?
choices: It gives him a great opportunity to run with everyone.
